New iron is required for swords, for shields, for war; not all of Nehekhara is left to rot.
This city lies in ruins. Nothing remains but destruction, ashes and the sorrowful taste of defeat.
Emerging from man-sized sinkholes, scurrying shadows ruthlessly silence anyone with forbidden knowledge of the Under-City’s existence.
From assigned posts, clandestine killers keep the surface-dwellers oblivious to the menace that skittishly plots beneath their feet.
All manner of questionable items eventually end up here. Buyers beware, however, as pickpockets relieve customers of their valuables almost immediately.

You are required for war. You will not ask questions. You will fight, or die. Perhaps both.
Dark Elves do not ride to battle, they ride to slaughter.
Beneath a blackened sky, with malice in their soul, the Druchii make ready for war.
Shrines to the God of War and Death are constructed upon ritual sites, brimming with magical energy ripe for the channelling.
Awake, awake, awake in fury. Rise thou with terror and twisted countenance, o God of War and Death. For the sands must feel thy wrath and thy subjects, war’s quickening madness. All praise to you!

A Cold One's preferred domain - when not on the hunt - is a cave, where they can better regulate their body temperature.
All Trolls love a good cave, but the Norscan variety prefer them as frosty and frigid as possible.
Shrines to Ursen are rare, but temples are even rarer, with only the sacred groves in the capital and Erengrad known.
The Father of Bears cares little for grand edifices, but in Kislev bear caves or standing stones are considered sacred.
Frozen tunnels under the ancient ice harbour unimaginable nightmares, offering no shelter from Chaos’ mutating influence.
Deep within the bog, fiendish thugs wallow in waiting until the calling of battle.
Da Black Orcs don't mix with da other gits and prefer ta 'ave dere own fire ta throw stuff into.
This Bretonnian outpost in conquered Altdorf has been given over to the ruling duke.
Spawning pools defiled by Clan Pestilens; the half-formed creatures that emerge make for easy pickings.

The Knights of the Blazing Sun are dedicated to Myrmidia, their large chapter house emblazoned with her likeness.
Even the bravest of opportunistic Skaven thieves prefers to avoid confrontation.
A bit of clandestine threatening and extortion of those above ground is an effective way to generate funds.
The Skaven are masters of manipulating the wealthy, controlling them with fear to keep them firmly in their pocket.
As Winter grips the Deepwood the Eternal Guard begin their vigil.
To guard the wild places of Athel Loren requires certain sacrifices.
The kindred of Loec are not like their fellow Elves.
The citadel stands as a deathly warning to any who would oppose Malekith's hegemony over the Druchii.

True craftsmanship is a gift from the gods.
The pit is where many of the Clanrat packs congregate in a writhing mass to eat and enact their own petty plans and downfalls.
Favoured Clanrats, or those that have clawed their way through the vicious hierarchy, have a place in the barracks and access to better arms.
Deep in the warrens are the clan armouries; heavily-guarded by Stormvermin, it is the first place the Skavenslaves ransack.
The finest steeds for the finest Elves. So it has always been. So it will always be.
Some vaults should be kept an eye on, because sometimes the sleeping dead are not the only things down there.
The Liche King proselytises his master, Nagash; his Black Tower juts skyward, a declaration of his dark and cruel intent.
Da Dropz are where the Orcs like to relieve themselves; they particularly enjoy doing it in enemy settlements.
Greenskins like to "let da world know" a place has been conquered in the strongest (and stinkiest) way possible!
When a heap of crap isn't humiliating enough, the Greenskins can really "go for it" with a towering pillar of the stuff!
A stinky idol is not only a message to the enemy but a tribute to Mork (or Gork), using readily available materials.
A Troll's face made out of poo can be an intimidating thing to come across, depending on the quality of the "sculpture" of course.
The Old World has very few master swordsmiths, for they are the finest craftsmen in the realm and always in demand.
Dwarf gates are strong and sound, made from Dwarfen iron and put in place by Dwarfen hands.
The strongest fortress gates are protected by more than just steel and stone.
The gates of the greatest Kazads are banded in foot-thick steel, and guarded by the bearded sentinels of the ancestors.
Alcadizaar's pyramid stands as eternal proof of his sacrifice to prevent Nagash's nefarious plans reaching fruition.
A treacherous path, to be sure, but safety lies beyond to those who can navigate it.
These towering gates bar passage to anyone harbouring ill designs about Ulthuan.
Safety, friend. Come ashore; you're in the greatest city in the world, now.
The teeming tunnel networks of warrens do not just sprawl underground, but can riddle entire mountains and chasm walls as well.
Usually owned by a dominant clan, these places are much larger nests linked by an impenetrable maze of tunnels.
Packs of Skaven gather in smaller burrows often used as staging areas where clans make ready to burst forth.
Skaven cities sprawl beneath the ground like swollen ulcers, with other races' ruins shamelessly usurped into their erratic architecture.
Giant corridors and endless passageways run through these decadent Skaven hubs, where the ratmen mobilise in unimaginably vast numbers.
Such things are useful if you don't want to lose the lot - ship, crew and cargo!
Hand-forged in the Empire's industrial heartland, hand-stolen off the coast of Kislev.
Useful for keeping the ship moored, assuming it's a calm day anyway.
Surrounding the colleges are many conclaves, unions and societies where Wizards share knowledge and secrets.
Dwarfs know the secret of creating, not only Gromril, but puresteel also.
Within this ornate sarcophagus of blackened oak, Harkon plots his return. Perhaps a name for an even greater vessel to come?
May the God of the Skies bless the warriors that stride forth in his name.
Chaos is the despoiler and in its minions' wake comes corruption, ensuring that ruins forever have a foul taint!
The City of Kings is an eternal monument to the sovereigns of the desert.
Great beasts of burden and horrors of the desert, broken and made to serve their Undead masters.
Next to every great temple of the Mortuary Cult lies a covered pit in which its deadly, ophic guardians dwell.
Countless soldiers have fallen in battle. In the wake of Nagash, they will all rise to fight again.
Many a rider has lost their steed in the treacherous drifting sands. The corpses still litter the fast-holding mires.
The gathering place and centre of power for Clan Mors, where Warlords address their kin-lords.
The Tomb Kings' citadels dominate the landscape of the desert, fixed and imposing amongst the ever-shifting sands.
In this grubby, subterranean grotto, a secret project of Warpstone-powered mass destruction begins…
The power to bring down civilisations at the push of a button, contained in a laboriously assembled steel orb.
Kraka Drak, famous for its gemstone and silver mines, is so rich that an entire hall has been lined with thick silver sheets.
This monument, much like the man himself, is defiant against the otherwise unstoppable march of Settra's armies.
Goats are a favoured animal for rearing. This is in no small part because Dwarfs and goats share the mountainsides.
Goat farms comprise several herds kept in barns or other housings, perhaps even within the Hold.
Goat. It’s a tough, stringy meat, but then Dwarfs are tough too, and like their food to have the same qualities!
For all Dwarfs who work above ground, this is the Guild they turn to.
Deep below the Tower of Doom, all manner of beasts are kept and … investigated, in the name of greater power.
Even for desert dwellers, the spice merchants are insalubrious. Yet the precious spice, they continually insist, *must* flow.
From their raiding ports the Northmen pour out into all directions, intent on sending the world to wrack and ruin.
Norsca’s ship-building workshops enable their raiding Marauders to be the infamous scourge of the Old World’s seas.
The Dark Cultists studying within say they can see the future. To this end, they study tirelessly and without cease.
The dark tomes that are studied herein, and the vicious incantations practised can shake the very foundations of the world.
All together now... 'Yo ho, blow the man down!'
Somewhere safe to play card or dice after hours… and after lives.
Keep them fed or they're likely to break free and eat you!
The wreck of the Grand Theogonist's flagship has large bulkheads and hundreds of cannons that could be salvaged for a much greater purpose.
Under Itza, the Vaults of the Old Ones contain many secrets of the Ancient Enemy, and, some say, how to finally defeat them.
When the frenzy of murderous hysteria reaches its crescendo, a chaotic rolling tide of death shall surge upwards!
The intertwisted, seething mass of vermin grows, churning in anticipation of war.
The Dread Knights are a force both terrible and mighty.
Cold Ones were discovered in the jungles of Lustria, then tamed - by force - by their Druchii masters.
This ancient portal connects the benighted forest-ways of the world that currently lie dormant.
Don't stick yer finga inna Squig Nest!
The favour of the Dark Ones does not come easily – blood must be spilt by the gallons; war must be waged!
The deep red mineral glows with a supernatural presence and is much vaunted by the Nehekharan rulers.
Killing is more than just a sport – it is an experience that brings one closer to the Gods.
The dead return, unaware that what was once their grave is now also their home.
These expansive, decadent testaments to death now teem with clamorous, violent Unlife.
Mastaba or ‘houses of eternity’ are, typically, flat-roofed tombs. Like all crypts in Nehekhara, once built, settlements soon rose up around them.
Great monuments to the departed, twisted into far-reaching cities of the dead.
The dark visions of Unlife that emerge from these tombs will, when done, return.
This city lies in ruins. Nothing remains but destruction, ashes and the sorrowful taste of defeat.
Weapon burrows, where combustible Skryre techno-weapons are stored, are not jealously guarded because if incompetently handled the user will quickly perish.
For logistical reasons, Skaven clans have arsenals of their most successful and 'reliable' weaponry, kept secure with arcane locks.
An ancient portal connecting the forest-ways of the world, fully revived and tapping directly into the root networks of old.
Known simply as "the harbour", Erengrad is one of the largest ports, despite being under the control of its infamous Guilds.
The port encompasses the harbour and docks, from the bay to the mouth of the Lynsk.
There are many docks in Erengrad - the 'Doorway to Kislev' - goods arrive here from Bretonnia, Marienburg and even Norsca.
The sentient whirlpool at the centre of the Galleon's Graveyard pulls great sea-going vessels into its gaping maw, wherein Noctilus bides his time and awaits his chance.
Although Clan Moulder's Hell Pit is the largest facility of its kind, many Skaven clans have laboratories dotted throughout the Under-Empire.
In more advanced Clan Moulder facilities, growth vats are used to enlarge and engorge certain specimens, including Rat Ogres.
A legendary settlement lies in ruins. Nothing remains but destruction, ashes and the sorrowful taste of defeat.
Within the Blessed Incubator, the beasts of Hexoatl are kept, ready for the Old One Itzl to leave his mark.
The tanneries of Nehekhara churn even in Undeath; the stench of acid and death pervades the desolate streets.
We will continue to empty the Elven palace until every slight in the Dammaz Kron has been repaid in full.

Let's get down to business and defeat these scum!
Great minds come together to discuss the storm that gathers around the Elven race.
Horse bray and wicker, whilst soldiers look anxiously to  the horizon. They have all rallied, for battle is near.
Upon the southern horizon of Hexoatl, on the eve of the equinox, stellar pyramids will rise above the jungle canopy.
All that glitters may not be gold, but there are certainly copious quantities of it adorning Nehekhara's rulers.
An empire as proud and vain as the Tomb Kings' requires magnificent stones to be unearthed in ever-increasing amounts.
Athel Loren's borderlands preserve the forest by protecting outsiders from the dark spirits within.
The Old World has many mouths to feed; grain provides the grist for mills and the base ingredient for spirits.
Farms large and small cross the Old World – growing crops, especially grains, for the crowded towns and cities.
Wherever the forest breaks, large swathes of land are given over to agriculture, most of which is owned by nobles.

“We have thousands of such caches, and only a few of us know them all.”
None shall forget the names of mighty thirteen, and the twelve great battles through which they forged Bretonnia.
Here the full, horrid nature of the Druchii is on display for all to see.
Behind blackened walls, the Druchii plot and wait, ever furious, ever ready for revenge.
The Dark Elves do not live in luxury, nor do they want for it - they desire only fury and violence.
Gnarled and macabre parapets jut skyward, vengefully grasping at the sky.
Where the Druchii dwell, so too does brutality and disharmony make its home.
The great statues of Khemri can only be built from marble drawn by bone-breaking labour in the quarry.
A status symbol, a show of the Boss’ rising power and a place he can "ang me boots".
A Boss with his own camp to keep his boyz close is to be feared.
Goblin Big Bosses have a big tent, bigga than the lads’ tents with more skulls on it.
While the Archecclesiastium is technically the governing council of Myrmidia's cult, it has become the main temple's name by association.
From here, large quantities of plundered goods can be safely unloaded and transported inland for sale.
For the bolder pirate who fears nothing, and especially not death, for none can die a second time.
This useful inlet was carefully chosen for its geographical position - easy to locate at sea and impossible to spot from the coast.
Skeggi’s original founder named it for his daughter, constructing this magnificent hall at the start of his second Lustrian expedition.
Large trebuchets are made at dedicated facilities, where master carpenters work to bring these devastating machines to war.
As well as making weapon hafts and quintains, carpenters also work on larger projects - such as trebuchets.
Usually close to the trade depot, the Guild marketplace is a bazaar of grumpy, haggling, Guild factors selling their wares and services.
Trade depots are effectively inland, underground ports, where merchant caravans from all over the Karaz Ankor offload their wares.
The sensible pirate brings a bag along as insurance, for when insensible later on he may forget where he left his plunder.
If you're careful, and observe the correct litanies, a good haul of treasure will last quite some time.
From humble beginnings, enormous stashes may grow.
This city lies in ruins. Nothing remains but destruction, ashes and the sorrowful taste of defeat.
Lads, we're gonna need a bigger boat…
'X' marks the spot.
The barrios are another part of the heavily-populated Skink districts, where many crafts are practised and artefacts created.
The labour districts are where the Skink handlers farm out Kroxigor labour for favour or a price.
The Skink districts are busy areas, where markets thrive, goods are exchanged and reptiles from foreign cities meet to trade.
Having faced far more abominable beasts than the Skaven, the Northmen relish "pest control duties".
Milk and beef from cows, mutton, pork, and goat are all valuable commodities in a hungry nation.
At night, the mill by the blood-clotted streams begins to turn, mixing grains with grinded bone.
Larger cattle farms have more land and better, more permanent, housing for the animals they keep.
Sylvanian peasants tend to wretched farms, continuing the pretence that the realm's nobles are kind and generous lords.
There are farms that are little more than tiny, muddy fields, on which graze scrawny goats or cattle with shrivelled udders.
The low-born of Sylvania that have heartbeats must still make a living. Most do in the cursed fields, tending to withering crops.
With Karak Eight Peaks once again in honest Dwarf hands, making it unassailable is now a matter of the greatest import.
Having fought many great battles to take Karak Eight Peaks, the shiny loot acquired is the icing on the Greenskins’ disgusting, mucus-encrusted cake.
Humiliation and dishonour are the Dwarfs’ rewards, as the tombs of their Ancestors lie ruined and defiled.
The long-hidden resting places of legendary Dwarfs contain ages-old weapons of great power.
The effort expended to create the great Underhalls is matched only by the blood spilled when taking them back.
The Greenskins used the dark, hidden passageways to conquer Karak Eight Peaks, and through them they continue to maintain their vile threat.
Only the most skilful archer can craft in flint.
All Elves are required to learn the bowyer's craft.
There is no such thing as an over-stocked cellar.
A little intoxication is good for the soul.
Where the Shaggoths go to invigorate themselves, standing upon mountain tops to bathe in the tempest.
No one truly knows when and how Dragon Ogres gather, but they always assemble on ground sacred to their ancient pact.
Karaz-a-Karak, known as Everpeak, capital of the Karaz Ankor. It is the richest, deepest, and most powerful of all Dwarfholds.
A readily-accessible source of iron ore mostly means more deadly weapons for the raiding Northmen.
Greenskins love their gods, so will quickly carve effigies of Gork and Mork out of stone or other materials when they settle.
A totem pole rises above the shacks and tents of the Greenskin settlement as a sign of its success.
A boss pole is a material reminder of how powerful a Warboss has become. It's a mark of great power.
The catacombs of this impossibly ancient city conceal treasures that are not of this realm.
Quintex has stood since before the dawn of recorded history. Within its vaults lie treasures beyond comprehension.
The deepest chancels within Quintex may very well hold treasures and learnings that unlock the past, and foretell the future.
Skavenblight, the noisome capital of the ratmen, is the most infamous of all under-cities - a sprawling metropolis and chief lair of the Thirteen Lords of Decay.
A monument dedicated to the Hound God has been erected here – all fear the feeding frenzy that is to come!
Beneath Karak Izor’s frozen peaks, the Skaven exploit its massive copper ore deposits for the nastier weapons in their arsenal.
Burning with balefire, an unholy forge is a relic of Stirland's more prosperous days, now defiled and used by a Vampire's thralls.
The Bakers' Guild hall is dominated by a massive oven that channels heat from the forges in the lower deeps.
Dwarfen barley is a particularly hardy variety that can be grown on mountainsides and used to make beers and breads.
Stone bread is a hardy bread baked for a hardy people.
Once harvested, barley grains are stored in funnel-shaped granaries within the Dwarfholds.
A place to stockpile the trinkets, jewels, and treasures pillaged from those now either enslaved or dead.
Vast rewards of war flow in freely to those adept at the art of perpetual killing.
In the harsh north, to wage war is to subsist.
Kurnous guides the aim of those true of heart.
The finest goods in all of Ulthuan, or so they would have you believe.
A dizzying array of goods and wonderment. The Asur can learn much and enjoy much more, for the right price.
These artisans have studied their craft for many centuries; they are undisputed experts.
The Skaven know their rivals would happily burrow out spy-dens beneath them, the only defence being to spy straight down themselves.
According to the Norscans, those unable to defend their valuables have no business owning such things.
This harbour is large enough for larger pirate vessels to moor and unload.
Ships laden with seized treasure harbour here, their stashes well guarded in case of attack.
This shoreline is littered with putrid bivouacs, under which the pirates shelter in between voyages.
Among these decrepit lean-tos and improvised shelters, the Undead crews pass the time between missions.
These wretched makeshift dwellings house dead men and dark forces.
Only the Undead dwell here, among the trinkets and treasure they've taken as prizes.
A place of relative safety, where stolen booty can be split, counted and stashed.
Here, in this unholy place, dead men tell tales of high-seas plunder.
A monument dedicated to the Eagle God has been erected here – all fear its looming shadow cast from above!
A minor node on a smaller tributary of the Geomantic Web, comprising a lone ziggurat, often ruled by a later generation Mage-Priest.
Located on a lesser tributary of the Geomantic Web, comprising a ziggurat and surrounding barrios, and often ruled by a later generation Mage-Priest.
A small gathering of cohorts, usually a settlement along the Geomantic Web in thrall to a more prominent temple-city.
The temple-cities are where the Lizardmen spawn and live. They scatter the Southlands and Lustria, comprising of great pyramids, barrios and plazas.
All temple-cities are nodes in the Geomantic Web, but some are true nexus points - massive cities and major tributaries in power.
The Altdorf Colleges of Magic teach gifted students from across the Old World in the ways of Battle Magic.
In the City of the Moon sits the Temple of the Eclipse, its power reverberating whenever the two moons align.
There is a cabin in the woods, you know, where darkness dwells eternally…
What is crafted by the Druchii endures the fires of war and the ravages of time.
Those who cannot find the strength to be free will have freedom taken from them by those who can.
If it is Druchii-made, then it is built for endless war. None of this gilded and useless Asur nonsense!
The sea-faring High Elves of Cothique built grand edifices into the cliffsides, creating palatial underground cities.
From within, the Blood Queen unearths new and excruciating methods of murder.
In the desert, decay sets in fast. Preservation is key, for food and flesh alike.
Rather fitting for a great pirate lord, don't you think?
Adjacent to the bridge, the sea cabin contains basic amenities, so the cap'n is never too far from the action.
At last! I've made it, Bernard - I've got me own room… Well, me own box anyway.
Here, decisions are made, booty is split, meals are ravenously consumed and tired freebooters rest their weary pegs.
When your boat's not that big, each space must have several different functions.
Palace of the Eternal Emperor, seat of the von Carsteins now and forever.
Surrounding the colleges are many conclaves, unions and societies where Wizards share knowledge and secrets.
Brightstone is highly valuable. It's therefore a pity that the mines at Mount Gunbad are infested with Night Goblins.
Within the great plateau of this ancient construct is the stellar engine; the secrets of its construction jealously guarded.
The great Elven capitals stand proud and vast, so that all may gaze in wonderment.
Look upon an Asur city, and let none think the High Elves any less resplendent or mighty.
Even the noble High Elves must have humble beginnings. Well, some of them.
The tower strikes defiantly into the sky, and the Elven settlement flourishes in its shade.
Though the Sundering left its scars on the world, the High Elves endeavour to rebuild and endure.
The hatcheries are tall pylons that nearly match the peak of the central pyramid. Within their tips are nests containing many Terradon eggs.
Here, saltpeter is mixed with black powder to improve its potency.
When the Undead destroy, the defender’s spirits are left to haunt such ruins - a callous reminder of their failure.
The heat-bleached bone warriors of grim countenance watch over the battlements, watching for foes through hollowed sockets.
The hieroglyphics inscribed upon these battlements channel protective wards, fending off any would-be invaders.
These lithified walls have seen empires rise and fall, and endured the accession of doom. They hold.
A Savage Orc camp is an even more disorganised rabble of tents than a traditional Orc settlement.
Savage Orcs can Waaagh! just like any Greenskin, giving thanks to Gork or Mork before charging off.
Savage Orcs are nomadic, but there are certain areas, deep in the Badlands, where they gather.
It is said that the trees of Athel Loren have eyes… and ears.
The protection of Athel Loren is paramount to all Asrai.
The Deepwood is ever vigilant.
Where the followers of Loec guard his secrets from outsiders.
Inside the Trickster's grove, his acolytes learn the many ways of mischief.
More lumber must be sourced to prop up the crumbling edifices of ancient empires…
Despite everything, the skeletal populace of Nehekhara do so enjoy a good vintage…
Marienburg is not a safe place in which to loiter, although the riches that pass through make it worth the risk.
The greater harbour of Marienburg lies past the Manannspoort Sea, just beyond Rijker's Isle.
Marienburg's infamous port, the Rijkspoort, is where the majority of the 'legitimate' goods arrive.
The wending limbs and hollowed nooks infer the subversive and twisting nature within.
Elven vases and other ceramics are some of the most beautiful artefacts in the world.
What was once a place of worship, reduced now to so much cinder.
Goblins have keener sight than Orcs, so the "scrawny gits" generally man the watch towers.
Orcs that get guard duty are not the Boss’ chosen boyz, they probably skulked at the back during a charge.
When warbands gather along tribal lines, they have likely been summoned by their Ruinous patrons.
Chaos' multifarious warbands range in size from small groups to veritable hordes.
The tribes of the far north set up camps, not for sustenance but for worship and bonding under Ruinous scrutiny.
Mourkain is the ancient Vampire kingdom of Kadon, who once controlled the Badlands. It was superseded by the Strygos Empire, of which ghoul-infested ruins still remain.
When the omens are strong, the Unholy Legion converges.
Only Everchosen have sufficiently risen in power to command a true Warhost of Chaos.
An ancient portal connecting the forest-ways of the world. Young shoots show growth along its withered state.
The manufacture of Warp-tokens directly from diluted chunks of Warpstone-permeated rock is a highly profitable enterprise.
A Warp-token stashed is a Warp-token earned.
Where Skinks come to show devotion to the serpentine Old One god, and warm-blooded prisoners are put to the sword.
A great fall crests the top of Sotek's pyramid, but it is not water that cascades down.
The site of many, many blood sacrifices of Lizardmen foes to the satisfy the Serpent God's eternal thirst.
Lairs of the dreaded Undead Terrorgheists are massive caves filled with the bones of their prey.
Once hunted, the creatures are stored in pens and cages for spectators or potential buyers.
In such underground markets, factors from Moulder and other interested clans come to barter-trade for specimens.
Skaven collect exotic creatures, but not out of curiosity. Clan Moulder will always pay a good price for new specimens.
“If them ratmen are around, we'll find 'em, just make sure the Zombie Deckhands keepin' watch actually 'ave eyes…”
Iron mines are the most common underground works.
Although little more than a horizontal mortar, the bombard still packs one hell of a punch.
These short, cast iron 'cannonettes' were made in the Imperial foundries at Nuln, guaranteeing their reliability, assuming they're always correctly maintained.
Hahaaaa! I’d like to see 'em come back after a broadside from these babies! Yarrrr!
Once-proud warriors reduced to pitiful, mewling minions who'd gladly kill each other for an extra scrap of bread.
Roll up, roll up - come 'n' get yer fresh mea… I mean able-bodied labour force!
Do not lightly rouse the Forest Lords, for when they finally decide to unleash their wrath, all the wood rages with them.
From such vantage points the paths and glades may easily be watched for trespassers.
Nothing enters the Deepwood without our seeing it.
On discovering a substantial seam of gold, a small mine needs fortifying against other treasure-seekers.
Gold matters far more to other races, but that weakness can be exploited, which gives the mineral value.
Elven gems are exquisitely cut. Dwarfs would argue that theirs are better… the Elves disagree.
Metal-working is known to only a few clans, while others scavenge or barter for forged weapons.
Skavenslaves are sent to excavate iron seams - they will labour until exhaustion.

A mound of black soil and knotted roots, upon which fell spells may be cast, rises from the ground.

Harpies are an omen of good fortune to the Druchii, and a foul omen to any who must fight them.

From small, ugly beginnings, hatchlings quickly grow into enormous and savage Black Dragons, horrifying and destructive.
Where the Throne of Power lies when in residence; where the High King sits reading the Dammaz Kron.
Goblin Big Bosses have a big tent, bigga than the lads’ tents with more skulls on it.
A status symbol, a show of the Boss’ rising power and a place he can "ang me boots".
The locus is a prism - a large geometric crystal floating in a constantly revolving state - and a junction where lines of power merge.

An obsidian turntable inscribed with hieroglyphs; when correctly aligned a new Geomantic pathway can be forged.
The Druchii give praise to the God of Smiths, in the hope he will bestow the legendary artefacts upon them.

There are always those without any formal medical training, who know older ways and which herbs will cure which ills.

For herbs that prove difficult to acquire, growing them artificially is the answer.
Formed in an ancient Elven stronghold many centuries ago, the city of Couronne houses the palace and ruling court of King Leoncoeur.
Pelts are placed on a grim totem, then taken into war by the herd's most fearsome warriors.
Burrows inhabited by Gors often have stinking and gore-infested hides around their entrances.

A rudimentary shelter furthest from the camp's pyre, little more than an indent in the bony ground.
In Naggaroth, there is no such thing as not shooting the messenger…
Those creatures raised by the Druchii raise are assuredly as cold-hearted as Naggaroth itself.
The Court Hall are where the Undead nobles, and living thralls come to play games of courtly intrigue.
What was once a place of worship, reduced now to so much cinder.

Perhaps there is some spirit trapped within, burning in abject agony every time the kilns are lit?
The employment of Night Goblins, who know how to avoid being tricked into the Skaven’s backstabbing plots, ensures the underground is watched.
Finding the right kind of crew - not too green but still hungry for war and lucre - doesn't have to be a difficult matter.
Here, some of the greatest right-hand men in history are laid to rest… temporarily at least.
Keeping all your potential recruits in one place makes mustering a far more straightforward process.
A fine resting place for the most audacious naval commanders of all time, until the time comes for them to serve once more.
The court of Avelorn is a great carnival, pitching silken pavilions in which Elves make sport and recite epic poetry.
Warp-turbines cost thousands of Skavenslave lives while in operation; a small price to pay for the development of the infamous Doomwheel.

Large caverns, close to the surface, are often used as workshops, where Skaven war machines are built, laboured on by thousands of expendable slaves.
The preferred route of the magic-using servants of Chaos, an arcane vortex is for the damned alone to step into.
A tear in the fabric of the mortal realm from which Daemons and other horrors can - and will - emerge.
Jungle lotus is one of the most potent of plants, and only a few know where it grows most regularly.
Some Skinks have an innate knowledge of which jungle berries to use to salve bites and other nasty injuries.
The glory of Elven halls is unmatched.
The halls of the Asrai spring from the forest itself.
Deep beneath the earth and protected from the elements, safe from harm.
There are few places in Athel Loren that are punctured by the light of the sun.
From tiny acorns, great oaks may grow.
Night Goblin Shamans tend to reside in hovels - mouldy lairs deep underground and surrounded by fungal patches.
Shamans live apart from their green-skinned kin.
The first of Nagash's great and powerful edifices. Even millennia later it is still surrounded by fell magic.
When peasants start vanishing, it may be necessary to start a night watch lest the lords and nobles be next.
From high in the lush forest canopy the Handmaidens observe Alarielle's court, awaiting her summons.
The creatures that take flight flock to the Shrine of Birds, the Old One whose essence resides within awarding all creatures that take flight.
The great hangars of Karaz-a-Karak are the home of its infamous Airkorps.
Only the most reckless individual would dare attempt to somehow pull celestial objects out of the sky… cue Ikit Claw.
The observable secrets of the Dark Moon shall become clear.
Some battles are fought over areas drenched in magic. The corpses that litter these sites are ripe for Necromancers…
All the best places are ones you've nicked from other races and then made your own by leaving piles of poo and shiny stuff everywhere.
Once the proud Hold of Karak Drazh, it is now the most formidable of Orc Strongholds, in the hands of the Red Fang tribe, until very recently.
The lairs of Trolls are fetid and disgusting; the further north they are, the more disturbing they become.

The digging out of hidden burrows beneath unsuspecting settlements is the first step of the Skaven's infiltration tactics.
Perhaps lacking the charm of the usual digs, but these underground Skaven hovels are still a home away from home.
The lairs of the ratmen remain unseen by the other things, but just below the world the Skaven lurk, ready to invade.
Here the Warlords and Chieftains scheme and plan, mustering support from lesser rivals while dodging the inevitable assassination attempts.
A hub of subterranean military might symbolising the influence and power of those in control of the Under-City.
This once-bustling port lies in ruins. Nothing remains but destruction, ashes and the sorrowful taste of defeat.
From the safety of a fortified position, warriors fire destructive ordnance upon approaching attackers.
The fetid, shambolic temple is a maze of tunnels that all lead to the Altar of the Great Horned One.
Those Bretonnian subjects who worship the vengeful Sea-God must do so in secret, as in some quarters even uttering his name can mean summary execution.
Giants stride the world, mostly in an intemperate stupor. Those that wander too far north are enslaved and corrupted by Chaos.
Gatherings at this place are… dour affairs, you might say.
The services of the Assassins do not come easily, or cheaply, but their shadowy skills are beyond reproach.

It is their lot – the miserable, undeserving rabble should expect nothing less.
The clothier turns the bolts of cloth from mere linen to garments – anything from shirts to large, frilly pantaloons!
For some, fashion is as important as a sharp blade to have upon your person. Tailors offer such bespoke stylings.
The tree-lined courts are where kindreds send their princes to increase their status through fine deeds.
Sylvania's woods are dingy copses of twisted, half-rotted trees that claw what nourishment they can from the bone-strewn soil.
One who is well-versed in the secrets of shaping ores into gun and artillery barrels. It is a skill set in much demand.
Dark and yellow-leafed forests surround the wind-swept moors of Sylvania, where criminals and far darker, hungrier, things lurk.
The Empire’s war needs cannot be matched by a single forge, so large foundries are built to keep up with demand.
Master Engineers are eccentrics, their workshops home to crazy inventions and devastating weapons.
The trees in Sylvania are as evil as its denizens, for they shelter many predators such as Fell Bats and Dire Wolves.
What mysteries lie behind the curtain, what beauty behind the final breath of cloth?
All ships that shove off from these docks are blessed by Manann, ready to face whatever might await them.
Trade and prosperity flow into Bordeleaux through this port, and with it, strength.
What little boats may ride the waves from here are still hardier than any other in the Old World.
Jungle clearings and waterholes are where prey will gather; these are often protected by Lizardmen as a form of husbandry.
Lizardmen, especially Saurus, are meat-eaters, and so many animals are bred to slaughter and consume.

A pleasant place to rest at the end of a long day of plundering the high seas with your mates.
The once beatific fortress of Mousillon is now a decrepit pile, but still a formidable stronghold for the living to attack.
Dwarfs can carve magical runes into anything, but they can only mark obsidian with permission from the Guild.
The business of secret murder makes the establishment of escape routes, secret tunnels and concealed hidey-holes a necessity.
Unbeknownst to most - often even the ranking Warlord - Clan Eshin has their own outpost or den within the lair, where Eshin members gather to plot.

Submerged in toxic green smoke, gas-masked Engineers preside over unventilated vat-filled warrens where Warpstone is optimised for best use.
This palace is the result of years of back-breaking labour. Somebody else's, of course. Not mine. No, no!
If you're good, you'll run out of pockets very quickly.
This space is big enough to store plenty of stolen goods and new-found long-lost treasure.
For the really big hauls - the live ones you can't really keep anywhere else.
A simple pole and ring system allows the helmsman to control the tiller from the deck.
Squigs are choice morsels – there aren't many Orcs that can turn down a roasted one!
A wheel is best - you can almost turn your boat on the head of a pin and cut them off before they can run.
While Greenskins will eat meat raw - they certainly have the gnashers for it - they do, in general, prefer to have it cooked.
Orcs like to eat, and they’re not choosey - game, enemy corpses and even their mates are all potential menu items!
A basic arrangement that enables crude steering, but isn't ideal if you want to make swift manoeuvres.
The addition of a keel adds a great deal of stability to a ship's structure.
The bigger the ship, the more bulkheads, stringers, webs, girders and frames can be fitted, meaning more room for crew and loot.
Rub a dub dub, two 'undred men in a tub…
Shrines to certain lesser or forgotten Old Ones are scattered throughout the temple-cities; no matter how insignificant, they are still highly revered.
The great pyramids and temples are normally clustered at the end of the grand plazas at the centre of the temple-cities.
Temples of the Old Ones populated by many Skink acolytes and dedicated Mage-Priests are found throughout the temple-cities.
The deft creation of cloth is one of man's specialities. Their flamboyant clothing couldn’t exist without weavers.
The clothier turns the bolts of cloth from mere linen to garments – anything from shirts to large, frilly pantaloons!
For some, fashion is as important as a sharp blade to have upon your person. Tailors offer such bespoke stylings.
Larger Holds have greater shrines dedicated to the Ancestor Gods; Grimnir is the warrior god and patron of Slayers.
Members of the Slayer Cult worship at the nearest shrine, when not seeking death.

Deep within an icy labyrinth strewn with the gnawed corpses of once-mighty heroes, sits the Troll King’s rocky throne.

Smaller taverns are often little more than rooms with kegs of ale stacked along one side of a hay-strewn floor.
In times of war, the large lagoons in the Saurus caverns can be adjusted to gestate many warrior cohorts simultaneously.
This city lies in ruins. Nothing remains but destruction, ashes and the sorrowful taste of defeat.
The Temple Guard are placed in a dedicated barracks where they train and bask awaiting their sacred duty.
Skink aggregators believe that cooler spawning climates found under the ground can produce better quality warriors.
Unsurprisingly, clay pits hold vast amounts of clay, a malleable material that hardens when baked.

Kilns are large ovens mostly used by local potters, who bring their merchandise to be baked prior to sale.
Skavenblight is the centre of all Skaven power, where the Lords of Decay meet to decide the fates of all.
The Druchii worship the brutality of Khaine above all, founding centres of agony in his name.

The dark visions of Unlife that emerge from these tombs will, when done, return.
Great monuments to the departed, twisted into far-reaching cities of the dead.
The once-great court of Avelorn now lies sacked and broken in the wake of savage Druchii terror.

These expansive, decadent testaments to death now teem with clamorous, violent Unlife.
It's not actually hidden, it's just that most are just too afraid to go there.
The dead return, unaware that what was once their grave is now also their home.

An ancient tower clad in pure gold, constructed by the Lizardmen at the order of the Old Ones in an age long past.

It may look like a motley collection of huts and boxes, but here, seeds of greatness flourish.
When they come for you, be ready.
Every legendary enterprise has to start somewhere.
The pure, unfiltered darkness oozing from this altar is enough to give even the hardest Druchii pause.
Far more than just a simple hideout, this place has genuine pirating potential.
A highly-defensible location; tricky to assault and with plenty of room, it's the ideal place for pirates to rest up between actions.

Up-righting wooden shafts to create a stockade or a low stone wall may hinder the enemy, but will not keep them out.

Cities are usually ringed by high walls of stone to defend against threats within and without the nation’s borders.

Weird-stone not Warpstone! Smooth and lined, but some warlords like it…
This port-town lies in ruins. Nothing remains but destruction, ashes and the sorrowful taste of defeat.
More enterprising Dwarfs seek their own fortune and join colonies away from the greater Holds.
Dwarf Keeps are the bastions of the realm, impregnable forts built upon and within the mountain peaks.
Dwarfs do occasionally live above the ground - there are outposts scattered throughout the World's Edge Mountains and beyond.
The Dwarf fortress-cities - the Karaks - are truly a site to behold. Each an independent kingdom, together they form the "Karaz Ankor".
The greatest Dwarfholds are the most legendary; the mightiest strongholds, led by greatest kings of the age.
Smaller vineyards can be nothing more than a farm with a few rows of grapes, with a yield hardly worth taxing.
When a Vampire drinks an "aged red" from a wine glass, chances are it hasn't been made from grapes…

The Empire’s southern provinces have a modest wine industry, but nothing compared to Bretonnia's vineyards.
Sylvanian orchards contain low-hanging, spooky trees, whose thorny branches are as likely to grab a passer-by as provide fruit.
Valuable metal blades - taken during raids - are placed in a mound or stood against the herdstone itself.
Although the tribes have little use for opulent construction materials, marble’s availability in the north makes it important to Norscan trade.
Once given weapon and armour, Gors go to the horned totem to be blessed by the Granter of Savage Hate.
In blessed pools will the Slann bathe or stare - often for decades - until enlightenment is found.
The Empire is riddled with homesteads, farms and tiny groups of sullen houses filled with sullen folk.
Villages dot the Empire, usually comprising a marktplaz, a tavern, and a stockade – if their denizens are lucky.
The towns of the Empire are walled islands of civilisation amidst the unrelenting and hostile wilderness.
Cities are massive places, crammed with ramshackle buildings  – all teeming with the stench of mankind.

Woodworkers, while not as skilled as carpenters, are as fundamental to the realms of men as builders and blacksmiths.
Those unfortunates caught within the forest when the Wild Hunt is running find a nobler purpose through sacrifice.
The fleshless faces of the dead stare out in warning to all enemies of the tribe.
Nothing saps the courage out of an enemy like a massive wall of dead bodies.
When attackers are foolish enough to challenge a Norscan enclave, these ramparts drip crimson, drenched in their blood.
The pyramid of the Imperishable commands the respect and dread of all who gaze upon it.
During a gathering of tribes or 'moot', many sacrifices are thrown into a large fire pit as the Chieftains parley.

Shrines of Myrmidia can be found in most southern provinces. They are well ordered, martial places, as befits their deity.

The trappings of life, endlessly recreated in death.
Gnawed bones and scraps of cloth is all that remains of those caught in the path of a Skaven scavenge-raid.
The Skaven can sustain themselves on most races’ foodstuffs, which they pilfer indiscriminately regardless of freshness.
The larger a village becomes, the more significant and vile its shrine to the Dark Gods.
Wherever dark energies can be channelled, the seers commune with godlings and daemons to guide the tribe towards war.
The Chaos Gods exist, as undeniable as the night. They are worshipped at Ruinous Altars, intended for sacrifice and more.
To worship war is to endlessly indulge in it until death, or into immortality – whichever comes first.
Sigmarite Shrines vary from roadside memorials to more substantial chapels that hold a small congregation.

Even in the vast desert, there are beacons of hope that give way to phantasms of decay.
Temples of the Sigmarite Cult are bedecked in holy comets; they are altars to the Warrior-God – founder of the Empire!
Grail chapels dot the landscape, sacred places often protected by a Grail Knight.
The largest shrines can be found in major cities, yet the pious say the Lady is absent from such self-acclaimed edifices.
Shrines to the Lady are usually small groves near a pure water source, adorned with fetishes and tokens of the Lady.
The dark stones of the Obsidian mines glint with a deathly, otherworldly gleam.
To repair his fragmented psyche there are no depths to which Harkon will not sink.

The biggest and bestest Warbosses rule from formidable strongholds - the shattered Karaks of the Dwarfs.

Often formed from the upturned hulls of old longships, a hall is where a Chieftain will feast and receive visitors.
Wolves are rarely penned in, for to keep such creatures against their will is a mistake.
It is in the gloomiest, dankest parts of the forest where the Spiders make their nests and lay their eggs.
Deep in the forests, the children of the many-eyed and many-legged "Feasters from Beyond" lurk.
Some fish are considerably less benevolent than others.
From the darkest depths, the hideous, pulsating masses rise…
Amongst the coastal swamps, dark shapes shimmer and twist, waiting for the command to strike.
This city-port lies in ruins. Nothing remains but destruction, ashes and the sorrowful taste of defeat.
Only ill-adjusted minds worship the Underworld's vengeful Pale Queen.
Ossuaries are the resting places of skeletal remains, originally reserved for Morr's greatest subjects, but long since defiled.
A vile place of discarded gravestones, statuary, rotting limbs, headless bodies that still crawl, and lots and lots of bones.

Here the High Elves may give praise to the ruler of the Elven pantheon, Asuryan.

A stone cutter fashions large hunks of stone, for ease of transport and in preparation for construction.
Large marble deposits are quarried for use in opulent residences and grand halls.
A mason is more than a mere stone cutter, he adds craft to the role and is able to form grand shapes from his chosen material.
Warhounds that accompany the Beastmen are kept in crude dens, where they are fed prey - both living and dead.
There are places in the blood-grounds were suppurating wounds burst from the ground and poison fumes belch from crags.
In the deep pits are kept Chaos Spawn, blessed with a multitude of gifts from their Dark Gods.
Where there is demand for something, you can bet there'll be someone willing to risk all to bring it ashore.
Early following the establishment of a camp, Ungors are sent scurrying away to find wood for fires and other uses.
The tribe's Razorgors are kept in rough, makeshift sties that cannot hold them should they show their teeth.
Leering over the landscape, an ominous sentinel keeping would-be brigands in check.
Roots are the source of all life.
A hoard is not just a heap but multiple piles of shiny fings!
A heap of shiny stuff is like a pile but bigga!
High above the darkened groves of Athel Loren rests the Canopy of Hysh.
A pile of shiny stuff is what the Greenskins have collected from raidin'.
The Winds of Ghur blow fiercely through the Deepwood.
From here, Elven outposts are connected to Athel Loren via the Worldroots.
It is only fitting that the great Black Pyramid is under Undead ownership.
What's been destroyed can be recreated.
Be wary of the Undead bearing projectiles.
If it goes bang and doesn't blow the shooter to pieces, who cares where it came from?
There's a fair chance that some of them won't work and some will explode, but that's not so important as their owners are already dead.
The manor oversees vast tracts of land, and the Lord knows it is well worked and bountiful.
Elven nobility are proud, and some might say arrogant, but their estates are beyond belief!
Those industrious enough to claim free land for their own reap the benefits, so long as they pay tithe to the Phoenix King.
The boyz need big open spaces to swing their choppas about.
Giants, descendants of the Sky-Titans, are more likely to be found in the stompin' groundz than anywhere else.
This is where Big ‘Uns are forged and many teef lost to gambling.
Trolls can be found in their foetid lairs - dank caves or burrows, ankle deep in rotting bones.
A large area set aside for the belligerent gits to slap each other about.
The meanest and strongest of their kind, the Black Orcs rarely mix with others, preferring their own barracks.
The toolmakers' foundry is located away from the main forges, as their Guild is wealthy enough to install its own.
Despite their stubby fingers, Dwarfs create excellent, intricate and delicate clockwork for tools and other apparatus.
Toolmaking, as one of the most powerful industries, is represented by a Guild.
A tinker is adept at fixing things, especially metal items, which explains why the Dwarfholds contain so many.
While the Goldsmiths' Guild cannot match other Guilds' influence, they are certainly the wealthiest.
Gold has ever been lusted after by men and Dwarfs. Small mines dot the Old World, their owners hoping to strike big.
Once extracted from the mountains, gold is smelted into bars or even minted into coins.
On discovering a substantial seam of gold, a small mine needs fortifying against other treasure-seekers.
It is not just the meat that is used, animal skins and furs certainly have value also.
Camps are where Dwarf hunters assemble before their work begins.
Lodges, where hunters gather and store their prey, are located deep within the forested hunting grounds.
The Gemcutters' Guild is rich, by the very nature of the commodity in which it deals.
Members of the Gemcutters' Guild are respected both for their craft and for the riches they create.
Gem mines are valuable resources, especially if they have a high yield.
Mysterious shamanic ritual helps bring even the most powerful and destructive mutant leviathans under the warband’s control.
A gem mineshaft is for digging into the mountains in search of precious stones, something Dwarfs are very good at.
The various Norscan depictions of the Ruinous Ones are put on display for all to see.
The Leatherworkers' Guild is mainly found in the Holds around the Vaults and Grey Mountains, where plenty of manling customers can be found.
Knights Panther chapter houses are located deep within Middenland, although detachments can be found in armies across the Empire.
A simple shrine, to pray homage to the god of gods.
Make a little effort - you stand before an altar to the greatest god!
Splendour and magnificence, to pay glory to Asuryan.
Give praise to the Lord of Fury upon bended knee. He may listen.
May the Lord of War smile mercilessly upon your endeavours.
A mighty edifice, erected in honour of the God of War himself. Let his fury drive the Druchii to war!
The Slayer Hold of Karak Kadrin houses the greatest shrine to the Ancestor God, Grimnir, the first Slayer.
Arch-Necromancer Constant Drachenfels once imprisoned his victims within these crypts, so they could be tortured at his leisure.
Constant Drachenfels lived for over ten thousand years, constructing a vast library of ancient tomes and dread grimoires.
Within the damned reliquary is stored the true weapons of power, culled from temples and secret places beneath the world.
A collection of infernal weaponry, some plundered from southlanders, some fashioned by the Hellsmiths.
A pile of writhing corpses from which a shambling patrol of Zombies will emerge.
Throughout the cursed realm stand watchtowers of bone. Within are the Grave Guard - always on duty and ready to strike.
All Asur need a place to contemplate and prepare, for battle will come here soon.
Tunnels and warrens dug deeper into the bowels of the earth provide more concealment for nefarious scheming.
Gaze upon the majestic beasts of old and realise your place within the world.
It aids defence greatly when attackers can be turned to fight for them.
The Liche Lord commanded his great pyramid constructed, so that in life and beyond, all will know his resilience and dedication.
Spirits of long-dead warriors linger in the mound, eager to take to the battlefield once again.
Centigors are incapable of building their own shelters and so find hollows in which to rest and revel.
The strongest Centigors make their lairs in crude shelters or caves, daring any to challenge them for the superior residence.
Centigors can be found in the grassy plains bordering the deeper forests, where they try to outrun the elements.
The Goddess of the Savage Hunt exists for the thrill of the chase, no matter the prey.
There are some who do not wish to live in harmony, whose malice must therefore be contained.
“Don’t get too close – it burns with the hellish heat of the instability between worlds!”
Higher forge temperatures offer more than just bigger and harder axes, but also useful things like beast-barding and chariot modifications.
Smiths are usually thralls, stolen from the south and kept alive for their skills, with access to a very basic smithy.
Very nasty - tends to rip ‘em apart and send ‘em down to Stromfels’ Chest with all hands lost… to my true father's delight!
In locked chambers beyond the Hold's brewery, are the brewmaster's kettles. These are where the special and secret ales are brewed.
A Dwarfhold with a famed brewery attached is one worth defending at all costs, its casks as valuable as gold.
Proper roads facilitate trade and encourage travel. Bandits tend to be put off, lest they meet the Emperor's agents along the way.
In dis cave, da boyz often discover shiny rocks that may well be worth a few teef for da Boss!
More important than the gates that secure it, than the barracks that houses the soldiers, is a Dwarfhold’s brewery.
The infamous and renowned Dwarf beers are left to mature until needed.
Taking mines from da stunties gets their beards in a real twist, especially when da boyz nick all da shiny rocks in ‘em as well.
Public works must be paid for; invariably, it is the ordinary man who foots the bill.
Some pits are for throwing useless gobbos down, others have gold and other shiny stuff in them. Send in the sniffer squigs and claim it!
Skink hunters will oft make secret camps on well-trodden routes they know prey will roam.
The Old World contains many altars to its myriad gods. When the Beastmen come, these sacred places will be despoiled.
Cooling halls that shelter meat away from the Chotec's rage, the sun, helps keep the food relatively fresh.
More than mere dedications to the Plague Lord, piles of putrid, rotten flesh are points from whence Chaos flows.
Agriculture is not an alien concept to Lizardmen, they farm many breeds of insects, often in great domes that buzz with sound of swarms.
Scavenge-piles are where the useful accoutrements claimed and stolen by the clans after battle are placed for its champions to scour.
The scrap heap is made from the most valuable items scavenged from the over-worlds of the Man-things, Elf-things and Beard-things.
The worst pieces of broken swag scavenged from battlefields above and below, is thrown into the trash hole and fought over by the Skavenslaves.
Warhorse breeders excel at sourcing the bravest and finest destriers for stud.
Don't stick yer finga inna Squig Nest!
Empire Huntsmen are known for their skill with a bow. Camps are where they launch their forays into the forest.
To hunt here is to become the hunted, for the prey is vicious and probably dead already…
It is not just meat that has its uses, skins and furs do too - at the tannery.
What is the Flayer? A myth, but one that is all too real.
Lodges are located deep within the forested hunting grounds, where hunters gather and store their prey.
Should the smallfolk organise themselves, a whole expedition will venture into the haunted woods in search of game.
From here, the Dark Elves cast off into the inky waters, intent on practicing unspeakable cruelty.
Those brave - or foolish - enough to venture into Druchii territory may find respite here, however brief.
Cast off, if you dare, for these waters carry some stranger tides…
White Lions are proud predators that roam the northern forests, who in turn are hunted by Chrace's warriors.
Wizard come in all sizes and shapes. Funnily enough, so do their dwellings.
The Colleges of Magic are located in Altdorf, although the Orders have campuses in cities across the Empire.
Wizards are wanderers and often loners by nature but, should one or two of them meet, a conclave is formed.
Once recovered from the mountains, gold is smelted into bars or minted into coins of the realm.
A great furnace with an ornate, brazen face, and yellow-green balefire within its sneering mouth.
On discovering a substantial seam of gold, a small mine gets larger and needs fortifying against other treasure-seekers.
When does a sty become a farm? When there are lots of boars there.
When a Vampire Count discovers a large seam of gold, he will send his minions forth to scour it clean.
Gold has ever been lusted after by both men and Dwarfs. Small mines dot the Old World, their owners hoping to strike big.
The stinking, stubborn war boars are kept in sties, where visitors smell them long before they see them.
Gold found here is always tarnished and far from the pure element so beloved by Dwarfs. Nevertheless, it has value.
A filthy, broken-down place, where evil plans are hatched and dark plots germinate.
Somewhere to lie low, to count loot and plot fresh schemes.
This hive of villainy houses the Undead crews in between sea-borne raids.
Successful pirates get to enjoy some of their pickings; a lair is also a place in which to hole-up and live the good life for a while.
Get hold of enough filthy lucre and things get complicated - much effort must be expended defending it from friends and enemies alike.
The warrens are full-to-teeming with ratlings and immature vermin yet to prove themselves. Survival in this environment is brutal, harsh and often fatal.
Nest-nurseries are where powerful or special pups are taken to ensure they are not eaten by their ravenous siblings, or indeed their parents.
While some broodmothers are vaunted, such as the bearers of Stormvermin and other higher-caste specimens, the majority are kept in filthy pits.
An unholy font of dark dreams and trapped spirits, used by Undead Lords to bolster their legions.
Restless souls are lured by Necromancers into arcane wells and tethered to others for ever more.
In tribal villages, steeds are kept in corrals, which stops them from wandering too far and becoming Manticore quarry.
As the war-gathering grows, stables become more necessary to keep the myriad mounts and beasts confined and separated – especially from each other.
Taken from the steppes of the Northern Wastes, Norse steeds are kept at crude shielings, feeding on diluted blood.
Stabling yards are where the young nobles train with their steeds, leaning to shoot from the saddle.
The highly-prized pegasi of the Grey Mountains are kept in opulent 'sky-stables' known as aeries.
A place to hold the many dangerous and exotic beasts that would otherwise dwell in the wilderness.
A prison more than a stable, for those housed within are terribly untamed.
Liveries are more than mere stables – they are where the proud warhorses of the Empire’s Knights are kept.
Bretonnians ride to war on proud steeds generally looked after by a squire or stable boys in well-appointed liveries.
What defines a Royal Stable? When the equines eat better than their riders.
More rustic stabling is given over to the peasantry for their lowly geldings and nags.
Cinnabar, also known as blood rock, is a mineral which contains mercury, prized by alchemists and dye-makers alike.
Deep in the red pits can be found mercury in the raw form of cinnabar. A material often used in Dark Magic rituals.
Usually situated in the same noxious district as the tanners, a dye-maker’s plant also spills out fumes.
Best not choose the dark green powder, though, it certainly isn't snuff!
Blood rock mines are larger excavation sites for when substantial cinnabar deposits are discovered.
The Blood Mines are red as cinnabar - and occasionally Warpstone - are found here in significant seams.
In Conalxa's shrine do the Chameleon Skinks give thanks to the Old One who preserves and enhances them.
The scattered hamlets of Sylvania are even more isolated, parochial and pathetic than those of the Empire.
The peasantry live in small communities of inter-related families, and never venture far from their hovels.
Townships are little more than larger villages, usually within sight of a grand castle - its shadow looming over the terrified denizens.
When a Vampire marches forth, the cities of other realms fear - for should the Night Lord invade they become accursed places.
Dread, gothic citadels are scattered throughout Sylvania. They grow more ominous as their chief resident grows in power.
It is on the training field that soldiers first learn the most important of attributes, that of discipline.
On hearing the call to muster, it is to the rally field the regiments will gather.
Barracks are, by necessity, large billet houses for accommodating State Troops.
When the curtain rises, all assembled will fall prostrate afore the 'Siren of the Storm'.
The abominable Necrosphinx towers above the Nehekharans, offering protection and destruction in exchange for hushed and cowed adoration.
When the king calls a war council he requests his most capable warriors go to the Hall of Oaths.
Dwarfs called to war gather in their Clan barracks, ready for a Thane’s order to move out.
When the Dwarf throngs prepare to march it is to the mustering halls they come, ready for the call to war.
You never know when a grudge will need to be settled.
To summon vile minions, a circle must be etched in the ground, with symbols of a dead language scrawled around it.
An infernal lodestone is planted inside a binding circle, summoning the most powerful of all spirits as it glows.
The crypts of Sylvania can be dangerous places, for ghouls lurk and feed on the rotting remains within.
The secret meeting place of the Aesanar, the sons and heirs of the Shadow King.
Watch Towers are erected if a settlement grows to the extent that it is considered worth guarding against external terrors.
The militia forced to protect the camp tend to be angrier, more bloodthirsty, and hell-bent on having their day.
Norsemen guard their possessions and keep themselves safe from the harsh land's many predators.
The lower deeps of the Dwarfholds glow from the many war machines created in their foundries.
The secret of black powder, formulated here, is one shared only between the Empire and Dwarfs.
The wine market is a bustling and often dangerous place, as casks and bottles of the best vintages are sold for many gold coins.
As well as fashioning stone, the Dwarfs are also expert carpenters, as the workers in the siege workshops will attest.
The Lady herself blessed the Morceaux Valley, washing the land with crystal water from the Grail.
Vintners gather the grapes blessed by the Lady, turning them into wine for future generations.
Hangars, high among the mountain tops, from which Dwarfen air fleets launch.
The finest Bretonnian wines can be found in the Bordeleaux dukedom and the finest grapes in the Morceaux Valley.
It is not the sting of the Scorpion that kills, but rather its powerful claws and voracious, insatiable appetite.
The Bokha Palace is the seat of the ruling Tzars, a whole wing of which is fashioned from Ice Magic.
The local watch is garrisoned in the town barracks, the Knight-messenger's first stop when a muster is called.
For larger musters, a more populated area closer to the town is required.
On the village green, peasants are given sword, spear and a veteran warder to train them.
At the centre of the Bretonnian army is a core of soldiers, drilled since birth to be warriors par excellence.
Ancient warriors are found in barrows, usually at the sites of forgotten battles or the former seats of long-dead Chieftains.
The richer and more powerful the warrior, the grander his tomb. Such mausoleums contain great prizes for Dark Magic wielders.
Graveyards and cemeteries are ubiquitous - a particular favourite source of "fresh recruits" for Necromancers.
The Emperor's palace is the grandest edifice in Altdorf - home to the Altdorf Princes of old.
Only in forges blessed by Valaya, with anvils etched in protective wards, will a Runesmith ply his craft.
Gromril is the rarest of ores; no ordinary forge can get anywhere near hot enough to unlock its secrets.
Hold armies carry countless Dwarfen weapons, from ancient heirlooms to axes fresh from the forge.
The might of the Khemrian Warsphinx stands astride the cities of the dead, roaring eternally.
Obsidian is highly desirable for Norscan weapon-making, being much harder than other materials but more malleable in the forge.
The lightweight weapons of the Asrai are a mystery to other races.
A hunter is nothing without his weapons.
Down, deep in Hell Pit are where Clan Moulder keep their most promising and... foul specimens.
The mountain peaks of Parravon are known for their large bird roosts, but even more famous for pegasi.
There is a cabin in the woods… a place where someone, or thing, keeps certain other things…
From the ruined sawmills, Zombie bearers transport their cursed loads to large sheds long-thought abandoned by mortals.
Once part of Stirland's burgeoning timber industry, the sawmills have remained in a ruined, yet operational state since the Vampire Wars…
Foresting in Hunger Wood or the Spider Haunts is surely a fool's job?
Unusually, the Carpenters' Guild hall is lined with wainscoting and populated with grandiose benches of the finest timber.
Dwarfen carpentry exceeds that of Empire craftsmen, but wood is far scarcer in the mountains.
Wood is an ever-needed resource, and yet the forests of the Old World are not safe places to harvest it.
Lumberyards are wholesale markets where wood is stored in great quantities before being shipped to its final customer.
Wood in its natural form is hard to work with, so the timber mills turn it into lumber ready for sale.

By making deadly war machines Goblins can grudgingly get the resources they need to make even "betta stuff".
A few Goblins have a base understanding of concepts such as physics - much to the disgust of their fellow Greenskins!
The Lady may not provide salvation, but there is comfort in her gracious succour, which is something…
A rainbow array of vials and powders line the walls of these most aberrant and fascinating establishments.
This city lies in ruins. Nothing remains but destruction, ashes and the sorrowful taste of defeat.
Feeling a little under the weather? Oh, that's a big one! You had best come in…

Temple-cities close to the coast or major rivers will have designated port districts, where sea-going vessels of the Lizardmen make anchor.
Natural harbours fashioned long ago by the Old Ones themselves, and now used by their servants.
Pliodons are large, river-going creatures that seldom move on to land. They are used by the Lizardmen to ferry cohorts across bodies of water.
Often found high in the mountains, these checkpoints are mainly used by Dwarf Ranger scouting parties.
Although well hidden from lazy, non-Dawi eyes, Rangers barrack in strategic locations, ever-ready to spring into action.
The Underworld Sea is a cavernous ocean under Naggaroth that allows Druchii navies to swiftly travel from coast to coast.
The Elves of Athel Loren and their steeds are of one heart and mind.
True horsemanship requires a bond few but the Asrai understand.
Where Elven steeds graze, prior to the Hunt.
The king's most trusted Knights are given the responsibility of defending the walls and thus the realm.
At the court of the Phoenix King, many come to petition Finubar and play their intrigues.
Inside these filthy spaces, even-filthier pirate scum plan future endeavours and plot dire revenge.
The filthy hovels and huts are numerous enough here for a pirate community of sorts to have developed.
No one here lives, and can recall only fleeting memories of their lives before.

One of the reasons Eight Peaks rivalled Everpeak in greatness was the colonnaded hub of the Underway, in the lower deeps. This was a key crossroads, allowing trade and military access throughout the Karaz Ankor.

Beneath the Eight Peaks is a key nexus for all tunnels in the region – a junction that unlocks the World’s Edge Mountains for any ambitious Skaven Warlord. Whichever clan controls this hub can influence the entire Under-Empire.
What courteous words are spoken herein always belie a deeper meaning.
Fashioned from the tooth of a mighty Dragon, the lighthouse affords its owner a much better view of exactly what is out there.
Even the animals and beasts of Nehekhara could not escape Nagash's terrible curse, nor their masters' ever-living adoration.
…from which the great soprano - the Siren of the Sea, no less - connects with 'her public'.
The Elves of Athel Loren understand wood in ways lesser races do not.
A healthy horse is a mighty horse, and a mighty horse is vital indeed.
Mastery of their mount is vital to any would-be champion of the Asur.
Inspiration can be found in the eyes of another.
Devotion to one's art requires solitude.
Much like Warshrines, grisly trophies carried in the wake of Chaos Knights may attract the eyes of the Gods.
When a Chaos Knight's trophy haul becomes too large, a more permanent structure of bone and skulls is needed.
Normally found in northern towns and cities, the temples of Ulric answer to the great castle-shrine in Middenheim.
A shrine to Ulric, the God of Wolves, Winter and Battles and the patron of Middenland.
Strange, exotic - even sensuous - smells fill the air at this market.
Gathered from the far flung east, spices from many foreign realms can be traded here.
Races from the east come to trade and bring with them exotic wares and spices.
It is said that only this guild dares trade with the Dawi Zharr and other races even further east.
Clan Eshin has a tunnel network that reaches into the far east, of which they bring powders coveted by the other clans.
The servants of Hekarti toil away, ever discovering new, blighted ways to channel dark energy.
The Dark Convent offers its services, for the right price - and the price MUST be paid…
One of the most powerful and secretive of all Dwarf institutions, the Engineers' Guild can influence kings.
Dwarfen engineers are forever tinkering and refining their machines, doing so within their private workshops.
Sat atop the Ulricsberg, the fortress-temple at the heart of Middenheim dominates the city.
Some Vampires prefer sorcery to bladecraft.
High Elven ships carry goods to those with amicable intentions, and destruction to those who would do Ulthuan harm.
May Mathlann ever guide you back to safe harbour.
From Ulthuan shores to foreign climes, and back again; trade drives life.
The Badlands are... well, let's just say they're named appropriately. Therefore, when you've got lots of loot you need somewhere safe to stash it.
The Empire's greatest engineering minds aim to enter the centre of excellence at the academy.
A hook next to the tip ensures that a dart is rather difficult to remove, and struggling just makes its  gashed wound worse.
This barbed spear is ideal for hunting big fish, men, Orcs, Ogres - whatever!
Darts are for firing as well as throwing - with deadly results.
Three prongs are definitely better than one.
The addition of a rope stops the quarry from simply limping away to fight another day.
The experienced Necromancer knows all the nooks where the Fell Bats nest.
Stromfels' scaly backside! Duck! Now, quickly, get it with the tranquiliser harpoon!
Here, the winged monsters of the air settle and nest.
There, my pretties, promised you a feast, didn't I?
It is in Quetza where Sotek's followers are the most fervent. The ratmen should fear the coldbloods that emerge from these lairs.
Within the tomb of the Vampire lies its coffin, filled with loam from Lahmia. It is where the beast rests, waiting to be awoken…
A Vampire's keep is quite literally its castle - a dark, gothic stronghold from which it plots and assembles its forces.
When something is guarded by a garrison of Big ‘Uns it must be important.
Orcs that get guard duty are not the Boss’ chosen boyz, they probably skulked at the back during a charge.
Goblins have keener sight than Orcs, so the "scrawny gits" generally man the watch towers.
Beneath the frozen glaciers of Karak Izor's peaks lie gargantuan lodestones of copper ore that lend this proud Dwarfhold its name.
Drakenhof is the sprawling ancestral fortress of the von Carstein bloodline. Ever since the coming of Vlad it has been the de facto political centre of Sylvania.
Under the perennially auburn leaves of this mighty guardian, the forest grows and grows eternally.
Deep within the Chasm Glades, shielded from unwanted attention, the Forest Dragons lie sleeping.
The guard halls contain Dwarf Warriors, whose duty it is to defend the Hold from enemies both within and without.
The royal garrison are warriors from the king's own bloodline and Clan, and therefore the most loyal.
A small chamber, most probably in the deeps or close to the Hold’s vault, in which warriors on guard duty reside.
Located in the barrows or tombs of long-dead Chieftains are dusty racks of aged weaponry, still sharp despite the centuries.

Where the twisted Warlock Engineers of the Skaven manufacture their own brand of unimaginable doom.
Large stakes of pointy wood and other ramshackle defences of timber and bone are surpassingly effective.
A big wall is a good way of stopping an enemy from "gettin’ in".
If a camp is "stayin’ put" Gobbos will be sent out to dig a ditch around it as a basic defence.
The Temple of Mists is surrounded by enchanted fog that protects all of Xlanhuapec.
Saltworks are where brine is broken down and salt is extracted from saltwater.
Larger brine deposits need more intensive mining from pits which delve ever deeper into the ground.
Solidified salt is mined from brine wells. It’s an unpleasant and hazardous job, perfect for the underclasses.
Iron mines are the most common underground works of both men and Dwarfs.
Since before the building of Nagashizzar, Necromancers have used Zombies to burrow and mine mountains for their minerals.
Iron smelters process the raw iron ore, so it can be turned into steel or fashioned by smiths.
Cursed iron ore is laced with Warpstone. Such mines are prized.
The Saltworkers' Guild lacks influence but has very close ties to the Empire, its major export partner.
Iron ore is a necessity in a world that craves weapons and armour. Smaller mines usually comprise a single shaft.
The blackest iron ore can be found in the deepest pits, underneath the mountains upon which gothic castles perch.
Wood is blessed before it is felled, for that is the Elven way.
When the Lizardmen need wood, the jungle provides.
Found deep in the barrios, lumber from the jungle is bartered across the reptilian realms.
Wood in its natural form is hard to work with, so the timber mills turn it into lumber ready for sale.
Lumber yards are wholesale markets where wood is stored in great quantities.

A tumulus of corpses from a long-faded civilisation, now occupied by new denizens.
Underground lumber yards, held under by clans and their factors, where goods are exchanged for many Warptokens.
Warpstone-enhanced lumber is always needed in the Under-Empire.
The Clanrats of Pestilens are baptised in a font known as the Pox Cauldron; their pustules swell and their transformation into Plague Monks begins.
Often attached to the walls they protect, the guard house offers shelter and perhaps a hot drink for those on patrol.
Within the fell abbey, the Plague Priests preach to the frenzied plague monks amidst the putrid fog of the swaying censers.
The Watch is an organised constabulary; not always honest, but still a capable defensive force should the need arise!
From the unholy pulpits the Plague Priests chant and preach to their diseased congregation - sowing animus, disease and hatred of the no-furs.
Garrisons are occupied by state troops; dedicated soldiers placed to defend the settlement by the Elector Count.
A Dragon slumbers in lifetimes, waking only for mere moments of its life. Do not squander its time.
Ever since Caledor Dragontamer harnessed their power, the incomprehensible power of the Dragons has been a beacon of hope to the Asur.
Goblins, being consummate tinkerers, have figured out that a great big saw is a way to cut up wood… "and yer mates!"
